vclaim: "Our navy has shrunk from more than 500 ships in 1991 to 275 in 2016."
date: stated on January 20, 2017 in a statement on the White House website:
title: Donald Trump says the Navy has shrunk considerably since 1991.
text: President Donald Trump pledged to rebuild the United States army, which he said during his inauguration speech represented "a severe depletion." There is a foreign policy page on the newly renovated White House Tramp site that contains some statistics on the contraction of military forces: "Our naval fleet contracted from more than 500 ships in 1991 to 275 in 2016. Our air force is about one third smaller than it was in 1991. President Trump is committed to reversing this trend, because he knows that the dominance of our army must undoubtedly be." The size of the Navy fleet was a familiar point of discussion at least during the previous two presidential campaigns. But many of the previous allegations we checked the truth against the fleet to 1917, or 100 years ago, when the technology was quite different. Trump's claim is a more logical comparison. We found that his numbers were correct, and that there were valid concerns about the size of the Navy. The Obama Administration supported an increase in the number of ships. The spokesman for the Navy (Tramp) referred us to a maritime site showing the annual number of ships dating back to 1886. The Trump figures are accurate: in 1991, there were a total of 529 active vessels, and in 2016 there were 275 active vessels. The number of ships peaked at 6,768 during the Second World War. The number then declined during most of the twentieth century, with a slight rise during the Korean War and the Vietnam War. The number fluctuates slightly during each year as ships rotate into service and out of service. Lance Janda, a military historian at Cameron University, said that Trump ' s claim needed further explanation. "The thing is, numbers aren't everything," said Janda. "The ships today are much more expensive and stronger than they were in the past, so they are not as if our naval fleet is less capable than they were in 1991. It's also a question of what kind of ships you want to get. We tend to have fewer numbers of really expensive and capable ships. That's nice when they work. It's bad if you lose any. Holmes was in the Navy in 1991 on a ship that carried tomahawk anti-ship missiles that were able to hit enemy ships hundreds of miles away. Former President Barack Obama has already begun the process of marine growth. The White House of Obama has adopted a long-term plan that will raise the Navy to 300 active ships in 2019 and keep them at or above this level until 2045. The Navy completed a formal review process in 2014 to consider its future military requirements and, in March 2015, set a target for a fleet of 308 vessels. In December 2016, the Secretary of the Navy announced a recommendation for a fleet of 355 vessels, which he intends to include in the 30-year ship-building plan of the Navy for fiscal year 2018.
